description: From Middle English conduyt, condit, from Old French conduit, from Latin conductus. Doublet of conduct.

entries.meaning: A pipe or channel for conveying water, etc.
A duct or tube into which electrical cables may be pulled; a type of raceway.
(figurative) A means by which something is transmitted.
examples: The medium considered herself a conduit for messages from the spirit world.

entries.meaning: (finance) An investment vehicle that issues short-term commercial paper to finance long-term off-balance sheet bank assets.
